statement.text: Accessory renal arteries are present in 25-30% of individuals, typically arising from the aorta to supply the upper or lower pole of the kidney as end arteries; their recognition is essential during aortic surgery, renal transplant, and renal artery interventions to prevent segmental kidney infarction.

explanation.intuition: Instead of having one main blood supply pipe to each kidney, about a quarter of people have extra pipes. These extras usually supply the top or bottom of the kidney and have no backup - if you cut them, that part of the kidney dies.
explanation.key_insight: Accessory renal arteries are END ARTERIES with no significant collateralization. Inadvertent ligation during aortic surgery causes segmental infarction. Lower pole arteries crossing anterior to the ureter can cause UPJ obstruction. CTA planning is essential for aortic surgery.
explanation.technical_details: Embryology: renal arteries develop from lateral mesonephric arteries; failure of the usual arteries to regress results in multiple arteries. Prevalence: 25-30% have accessory arteries, bilateral in 10%. Upper pole arteries usually arise from aorta above main renal; lower pole from aorta, iliac, or main renal below its branching. Caliber typically 2-4mm. Lower pole arteries crossing anterior to ureter associated with UPJ obstruction. Clinical relevance: (1) Aortic surgery - must identify on CTA, decide reimplantation vs sacrifice based on kidney function, size, and whether it supplies >1/3 of parenchyma; (2) Renal transplant - multiple arteries increase technical complexity; (3) Laparoscopic nephrectomy - critical to identify all vessels.

location.upper_pole: Usually arises from aorta superior to main renal artery
location.lower_pole: Arises from aorta, iliac, or main renal; may cross ureter

aortic_surgery.management: Reimplant if >3-4mm, supplies >1/3 parenchyma, or solitary kidney
aortic_surgery.sacrifice_criteria: Small caliber (<2mm), poor kidney function, well-collateralized

renal_transplant.complexity: Multiple arteries require multiple anastomoses or bench reconstruction
renal_transplant.technique: May anastomose on back table before implant

UPJ_obstruction.mechanism: Lower pole artery crossing anterior to ureter

EVAR.concern: Coverage of accessory artery during deployment

imaging.CTA: Gold standard - multiplanar reconstructions show all arteries
imaging.MRA: Alternative, especially for renal function concerns

definition.@value: Additional renal arteries arising from the aorta or its branches, present in 25-30% of individuals, typically supplying the upper or lower kidney pole as end arteries without significant collateralization.

learning_objectives: Recognize the prevalence and patterns of accessory renal arteries
Understand the clinical implications during aortic surgery
Apply decision-making for reimplantation vs sacrifice
Identify the association with UPJ obstruction
clinical_pearls: 25-30% of people have accessory renal arteries - EXPECT them
Accessory renals are END ARTERIES - ligation = segmental infarction
Lower pole artery crossing ureter can cause UPJ obstruction
Reimplant if >3-4mm, supplies >1/3 kidney, or solitary kidney
CTA is MANDATORY before aortic surgery to identify all renal arteries
